surreal 0.0.0.9000
  • Reference

surreal

The surreal package seeks to implement the methods inside the paper “Residual Sur(Realism)” by Leonard A. Stefanski (2007, TAS, Vol. 61, pp 163-177). These methods allow for hiding images inside of residual plots.

Installation

You can install the development version of surreal from GitHub with:

# install.packages("remotes")
remotes::install_github("coatless-rpkg/surreal")

Example

To begin, first load the package:

library(surreal)

Next, we’ll retrieve R logo image included with the package:

# Load the R logo data included with the package
data <- r_logo_example()

# Display original data
plot(data, pch = 16, main = "Original data")

We can see that the data is in a 2D format.

str(data)
#> 'data.frame':    2000 obs. of  2 variables:
#>  $ x: int  54 55 56 57 58 59 34 35 36 49 ...
#>  $ y: int  -9 -9 -9 -9 -9 -9 -10 -10 -10 -10 ...
summary(data)
#>        x                y         
#>  Min.   :  5.00   Min.   :-75.00  
#>  1st Qu.: 32.00   1st Qu.:-57.00  
#>  Median : 57.00   Median :-39.00  
#>  Mean   : 55.29   Mean   :-40.48  
#>  3rd Qu.: 77.00   3rd Qu.:-24.00  
#>  Max.   :100.00   Max.   : -9.00

We can apply the surreal method to the data:

# Apply the surreal method to the data
transformed_surreal_data <- surreal(data)

After applying the surreal method, we get a series of additional predictors that when visualized against y look as if they are no underlying patterns.

# View the expanded data after transformation
pairs(y ~ ., data = transformed_surreal_data, main = "Data after transformation")

Finally, we’ll fit a linear model to the transformed data and plot the residuals:

# Fit a linear model to the transformed data
model <- lm(y ~ ., data = transformed_surreal_data)

# Plot the residuals
plot(model$fitted, model$resid, type = "n", main = "Residual plot from transformed data")
points(model$fitted, model$resid, pch = 16)

From the residual plot, we get back our original R logo that has a slight border around it to improve the original image recovery.

Acknowledgements

Prior work was done to bring the algorithms into R by John Staudenmayer, Peter Wolf, and Ulrike Gromping.
